author: By Kenneth Chang
title: June Huh’s monochrome chess puzzle paved the way for chromatic geometry.
description: He wanted to be a poet, then a science journalist. Only in his last year in college did Dr. Huh discover math as a calling.
content: Most top mathematicians discovered the subject when they were young, often excelling in international competitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Palestinian Outrage After U.S. Says Journalist Was Killed by Accident
description: The U.S. government said Shireen Abu Akleh was likely hit by a bullet fired from Israeli military lines in the occupied West Bank, but unintentionally, fueling claims that Washington isn’t impartial.
content: JERUSALEM — Palestinians expressed disappointment and anger at the United States on Tuesday, after Washington said it had concluded that Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian-American journalist killed while reporting in the occupied West Bank, was likely shot unintentionally by a bullet fired from Israeli military lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Granville
title: SAS, the Scandinavian airline, files for bankruptcy protection after pilots strike.
description: The carrier’s woes are part of a summer full of problems for Europe’s travel industry, including staffing shortages and walkouts by fed-up employees.
content: A day after its pilots went on strike, SAS, the Scandinavian airline, said on Tuesday that it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the United States, the latest reverberation in a summer of turmoil for European airlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Nearly 90 Years Later, Kossar’s Expands Its Bialy Operation
description: The Lower East Side fixture since 1936 will open stores on the edge of Hudson Yards and on the Upper East Side.
content: There’s no end of bagel stores across New York but for bialys, one name stands out: Kossar’s Bagels & Bialys. It’s been a fixture on the Lower East Side since 1936, first as Mirsky and Kossar’s Bakery, then, as of 1953, just Kossar’s. Now the company is branching into other neighborhoods, first with a store on the edge of Hudson Yards this week and on the Upper East Side in the fall. The bialy, named for the town of Bialystok, Poland, is not ring-shaped like a bagel, but round and chewy with more of an English muffin texture. They are made with a central depression typically filled with onions and, these days, you-name-it, like everything spices, olives and sun-dried tomatoes. The new store has no seating but also sells pletzels, a type of onion and poppy seed flatbread; bagels; and bagel and bialy sandwiches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David N. Hackney
title: I’m a High-Risk Obstetrician, and I’m Terrified for My Patients
description: A high-risk obstetrician explains what his patients will have to endure.
content: My wife and I practice in medical fields — obstetrics and pediatrics — that should be filled with happiness. And often they are, though we have selected sub-specialties that are often shrouded in sadness — high-risk obstetrics for me, and pediatric oncology for my wife. We have both watched children die while held in their mother’s arms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Jan. 6 Hearings to Resume Next Week With Focus on Domestic Extremists
description: Representative Jamie Raskin, Democrat of Maryland, has said he plans to show ties between Donald J. Trump and militias that helped orchestrate the Capitol attack.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol plans to hold a hearing next Tuesday to reveal its findings about the connections between former President Donald J. Trump’s effort to overturn the 2020 election and the domestic violent extremist groups that helped to organize the siege on Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Tallerico
title: Matthew Modine Isn’t Sure if ‘Stranger Things’ Is Done With Him
description: The Hollywood veteran returned to the Netflix hit this season, but not even he knows his character’s fate. “I would love to have the opportunity to come back,” he said.
content: This interview includes spoilers for the entire fourth season of “Stranger Things.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: At Wimbledon, Novak Djokovic Escapes Against Jannik Sinner
description: After dropping the first two sets to the young Italian player, Djokovic rallied to win three straight sets.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Novak Djokovic has pulled off some masterly escape acts on Centre Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: California Woman Pardoned 27 Years After Killing Abuser as a Teen
description: Sara Kruzan was 16 in 1994 when she killed a man who she said had sexually abused and trafficked her for years. A year later, she was convicted of murder and sentenced to life in prison without parole.
content: When Sara Kruzan was 17, she was convicted of murdering a man she said had abused her beginning when she was 11 and had trafficked her for sex at 13. She served nearly two decades in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Liu, Paul Mozur and Kalley Huang
title: In a big potential breach, a hacker offers to sell a Chinese police database.
description: For about $200,000, an unidentified person or group is offering what is described as data on a billion Chinese citizens. A sampling seemed to show the data to be genuine.
content: In what may be one of the largest known breaches of Chinese personal data, a hacker has offered to sell a Shanghai police database that could contain information on perhaps one billion Chinese citizens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Lawmakers ask F.T.C. chair to investigate TikTok’s data practices.
description: Questions are surfacing once again about whether TikTok poses a national security threat because it is owned by a Chinese company.
content: The leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee asked the Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday to investigate whether TikTok, the Chinese-owned video app, had misled the public about whether Beijing could have access to American user data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Russia’s tightening grip in the Donbas.
content: After Russia’s capture of the cities of Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk, Moscow controls the Luhansk province in eastern Ukraine. The Russian military relies on its superior firepower and on making grinding incremental advances — a strategy that is paying off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Anya Blau
title: As Her Album Takes Off, a Musician Struggles to Get Pregnant
description: In “Human Blues,” Elisa Albert explores the lengths one woman will go to for a baby.
content: A musician friend once spent hours in a greenroom with Robin Williams. He said Williams started riffing, and that was it. No one spoke and everyone watched, amazed at the ferocity and speed with which his brain spun out like a racecar on an oil slick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zixu Wang
title: Covid Outbreak Emerges in China’s Anhui Province
description: The country recently began to recover from a surge that shut down Shanghai for two months.
content: As China gradually emerges from a Covid-19 surge that shut down Shanghai for two months, an outbreak in eastern Anhui Province is posing a new challenge to efforts to balance economic growth with the government’s “zero Covid” policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey and Adam Stoltman
title: In Wimbledon’s Queue, Waiting Is a Pleasure, and the Point
description: In a world of online ticketing, camping overnight for tennis seats is an anachronism, but it is also about community and a sense of belonging.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — It was nearing 10 p.m., and Richard Hess, an 81-year-old American, was sitting inside his small tent and merrily preparing for his latest sleep-deprived night in the Wimbledon queue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Tumbling down his own landslide: How Boris Johnson lost his invincibility.
description: LONDON — When Boris Johnson won a landslide election victory for his Conservative Party in 2019, he loomed as a colossus over British politics, the man who had redrawn the country’s political map with a vow to “get Brexit done.”
content: LONDON — When Boris Johnson won a landslide election victory for his Conservative Party in 2019, he loomed as a colossus over British politics, the man who had redrawn the country’s political map with a vow to “get Brexit done.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Shifting Policy, France Brings Home French Wives of Jihadists
description: The country repatriated 16 women from Syria, in a move it had long ruled out. Thirty-five children, including some orphans, accompanied them.
content: PARIS — France brought home 16 wives of jihadists from sprawling detention camps in northeastern Syria on Tuesday, breaking with a policy that for years had ruled out repatriating and trying adult women who had left to join the Islamic State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gurley
title: ‘Ready to Rock, You Guys?’ The Winklevoss Twins Play Amagansett.
description: At the end of a tour that drew some social media mockery, the billionaire brothers’ rock band received a friendly reception at a venue close to their parents’ beach house.
content: The 40-year-old billionaire twins Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss have been on the road with their rock band, Mars Junction, since early last month, crisscrossing the country to offer their versions of songs by Blink-182, the Red Hot Chili Peppers, the Police, Pearl Jam and Journey. Tyler sings; Cameron plays guitar. On Saturday, they rolled into Amagansett, N.Y., the Long Island beach town not far from where they spent their childhood summers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: For U.S. Women’s Team, One Tournament Offers Two Prizes
description: The Americans can qualify for the 2023 Women’s World Cup and the 2024 Olympics by winning a regional championship. Their first step was a win over Haiti.
content: The Women’s World Cup is a year away and the Paris Olympics don’t start for more than two, but both tournaments are the primary focus of the United States women’s national team over the next two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Virginia Eubanks
title: His PTSD, and My Struggle to Live With It
description: After my partner was brutally beaten on the street, I became one of the many thousands of Americans caring for someone with post-traumatic stress disorder — and our relationship changed forever.
content: The night our world changed, I was in a copper baron’s palatial Adirondack home, writing about the history of the poorhouse. That afternoon, with the stained-glass reflections of autumn colors blazing through my window, I pored over an 1832 vendue contract auctioning the care of three female paupers to the lowest bidder in Sandown, N.H.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patti Davis
title: How Gun Violence Changed My Father, Ronald Reagan, and Our Family
description: There are people in America who want the rest of us to be afraid. History shows that every democracy that has crumbled did so in an atmosphere of fear.
content: Forty-one years ago, on a cold, drizzly day in Washington, four people were shot by a young man who had concealed a gun in his jacket. This was long before mass shootings became a frequent reality of our lives. It was long before semiautomatic weapons became commonplace. There were many “good people with guns” there that day. It made no difference. Four men were shot in a matter of seconds. I am the daughter of one of those men, Ronald Reagan, who came incredibly close to losing his life because the bullets John Hinckley loaded into his gun were devastator bullets, meant to fragment. Meant to kill more efficiently. One of those bullets blew apart James Brady’s head; he was never the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Ana Swanson
title: U.S. Aims to Expand Export Bans on China Over Security and Human Rights
description: The Biden administration is applying lessons learned from controls on Russia during the Ukraine war to try to limit China’s military and technological advances.
content: WASHINGTON — When Russian forces invaded Ukraine nearly five months ago, the Biden administration led dozens of governments in banning the export of advanced technology to Russia to hobble its economic and military development.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Analysis: Another loyalty test for Johnson could shine a light on a successor.
description: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson has survived scandals and setbacks that would have sunk many other politicians, in part because he maintained the support of his cabinet. But that changed in dramatic fashion on Tuesday evening.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson has survived scandals and setbacks that would have sunk many other politicians, in part because he maintained the support of his cabinet. But that changed in dramatic fashion on Tuesday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia’s Next Offensive
description: Plus Boris Johnson’s fight for political survival and Twitter’s lawsuit against India
content: With Luhansk Province firmly in its grasp, Russia set its sights on the next target in eastern Ukraine. Russian forces ramped up shelling on the outskirts of the city of Bakhmut as an apparent prelude to an offensive into the province of Donetsk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Sardine Soap for Fishy (or Garlicky) Hands
description: Hang this lemon-scented soap shaped like a fish next to the sink.
content: Naâma Laufer and Luis Correia, who import wines from Mr. Correia’s native Portugal, started a second company, My Portuguese Market, last year, selling handcrafted goods from Portugal. They have just introduced a lemon- and sea salt-scented, sardine-shaped soap on a rough cord. It’s ideal for hands that have been working with seafood, garlic and onions, and it’s easy to hang near the sink. The cute box makes it giftworthy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Where the War Is Headed
description: Russia sets its sights on the next target in the Donbas.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Larry Kramer
description: The July 5, 2022 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Larry Kramer. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Chiarito, Maria Cramer and Eliza Fawcett
title: The suspect and his family had long ties to Highland Park and a troubled past.
description: The suspect’s father recently ran for mayor of the city, where the family has had a presence for generations.
content: The family of the 21-year-old man identified as the gunman who fired into a crowd celebrating the Fourth of July in Highland Park, Ill., appeared to have deep roots in the community. His father ran for mayor; his grandfather was born in the city and was buried in a cemetery 13 miles outside of town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mira Jacob
title: Forbidden Art and Star-Crossed Lovers in ‘The Earthspinner’
description: In Anuradha Roy’s latest novel, several lives are shattered after the creation of a ceramic sculpture in 1970s India.
content: “What just happened?” I found myself asking aloud upon coming to the end of “The Earthspinner,” Anuradha Roy’s fifth novel. For several days after reading, I held on to a pinching disappointment — the novel closes without resolve, and I found myself returning to the book, wondering why Roy had built a world of such rich possibilities just to leave so many unrealized. Little did I know that this was just the beginning of what would become a complicated journey with the novel, leading me to a deep gratitude for this work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Will the Abortion Debate Keep Moderate Women in the Democrats’ Camp?
description: Worried about inflation and dissatisfied with President Biden, many moderate women have been drifting away from Democrats. Now the party hopes the fight for abortion rights will drive them back.
content: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — As Gov. Gretchen Whitmer prepared to kick off a round-table discussion about abortion rights at a brewery recently, Alisha Meneely sat at one corner of the table, feeling politically abandoned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Bad Bunny, a Streaming Heavyweight, Returns to No. 1
description: The Puerto Rican rapper, singer and pop star’s latest album, “Un Verano Sin Ti,” tops the Billboard chart again in its eighth week of release.
content: In its eight weeks on the Billboard album chart so far, the Puerto Rican rapper, singer and pop star Bad Bunny’s latest release, “Un Verano Sin Ti,” has remained a streaming steamroller, frequently topping 150 million online plays per week. This time, the album’s 160 million streams were enough for a return to No. 1, despite two new releases in the Top 5 and just 657 copies of “Un Verano Sin Ti” sold as a full album.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: ‘The Rise and Fall of … Jean Claude Van Damme’ Revives an Action Hero
description: A gleefully juvenile show about the Belgian star, from the writer Timothy Haskell, barrels through his life and oeuvre using toy action figures.
content: The New York International Fringe Festival is no more, but its spirit lives on at a second-floor black box theater on the edge of the garment district. There you will find “The Rise and Fall, Then Brief and Modest Rise Followed by a Relative Fall of … Jean Claude Van Damme as Gleaned by a Single Reading of His Wikipedia Page Months Earlier,” a new show whose descriptive title takes us right back to the heady days of such Fringe delights as “Theater of the Arcade: Five Classic Video Games Adapted for the Stage” and “Harvey Finkelstein’s Sock Puppet Showgirls.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: A Conductor’s Career, Cut Short, Still Blazes on Recordings
description: With an abundance of albums out on multiple labels, we have as complete a portrait of the Toscanini protégé Guido Cantelli as we are ever likely to.
content: Frost glazed the ground, and mist hung in the air, as a brand-new Douglas DC-6B took off from Orly Airport near Paris early on Nov. 24, 1956. The plane was headed for Shannon, Ireland, and then New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reem Kassis
title: Cooking Online, Arab Women Find Income and Community
description: Across the Middle East and North Africa, home cooks are using YouTube and their favorite recipes to transform their families’ lives.
content: When Heba Abo Elkheir was a little girl, she dreamed of becoming a lawyer, maybe even a judge. After earning a bachelor’s degree in law in her native Egypt, she married and soon found herself a mother of two.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Is gas green?
description: Climate advocates are warning against a European proposal to subsidize the fossil fuel.
content: LONDON — The European Union has an ambitious climate law to slash its greenhouse gas emissions by 55 percent by 2030.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: On Conservative Radio, Misleading Message Is Clear: ‘Democrats Cheat’
description: Election fraud claims from 2020 are widespread on talk radio, contributing to the belief that the midterm results cannot be trusted.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Nick Kyrgios to Appear in Court on Assault Allegation in Australia
description: The accusation landed on the eve of perhaps the most important match of Kyrgios’s controversy-filled career, a quarterfinal showdown with Cristian Garín.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — The spotlight on the Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios, whose confrontations with opponents and Wimbledon officials have made his matches can’t-miss theater for the past week, grew hotter Tuesday when news emerged that the police have begun legal proceedings against him for assaulting a former girlfriend in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Maria Abi-Habib
title: Has Biden’s Top Diplomat in Mexico Gone Too Far, Officials Ask?
description: Administration officials fear that the U.S. ambassador’s cozy relationship with the Mexican president has backfired, and may be setting back American interests in the region.
content: MEXICO CITY — Mexico’s election czar delivered a message to the American ambassador: The Mexican president was mounting an all-out assault on the national elections authority, sowing doubt about a pillar of the country’s democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Wife and I Lied About Our Son’s Death. Can I Come Clean if She Won’t?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on revealing a family secret, complaining about a tour guide and more.
content: A few years ago, my son died from an accidental overdose when he took a fentanyl-laced pill. When we got the autopsy report, his mother (we are divorced) wanted to keep the cause of his death a secret. I was reluctant, but in the throes of grief did not make a stand for the truth. We lied and said his death was due to a bad heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Simmons, Shawn Hubler and Noam Scheiber
title: Here is what we know about the victims of the Highland Park shooting.
description: A seventh person died on Tuesday. More than 30 people were wounded.
content: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill. — In the chaotic aftermath of the attack at a Fourth of July parade on Monday, Lauren Silva stumbled upon a bloodstained toddler lying beneath a dying man. As her boyfriend and son frantically attempted first aid, she cradled the little boy, who kept asking about his parents. As hours passed, word spread of the tiny child found at the scene of a massacre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Who is Rishi Sunak?
description: Boris Johnson appointed Mr. Sunak chancellor, the government’s chief financial officer and often second in power only to the prime minister, in February 2020.
content: LONDON — Rishi Sunak, who resigned on Tuesday as Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, has been arguably the most prominent figure in Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s cabinet, seen for a time as Mr. Johnson’s most likely successor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and The New York Times
title: As Russia Moves on Another Province, Ukrainians Leave Ghost Towns Behind
description: Vast stretches of eastern Ukraine are now largely devoid of people and industry. If Ukraine is ever to have a vibrant postwar future, it is unlikely to sprout from these ruins.
content: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — Nina Zakharenko cried when she boarded a minibus evacuating civilians as the Russian Army advanced toward the town where she went to college, met her husband and raised two daughters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: Crypto Crashed. Wall Street Won.
description: Plus, a legal twist for collapsed investment firm and founder Bill Hwang.
content: As Bitcoin prices have plunged and cryptocurrency start-ups have failed, Wall Street’s biggest banks and their wealthiest clients have barely taken a hit. Some have even managed to turn a profit on the collapse. In the great cryptocurrency blood bath of 2022, writes The Times’s Emily Flitter, Wall Street is winning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Glenn Thrush
title: Justice Dept. Sues Arizona Over Voting Restrictions
description: It is the third time the Justice Department under Attorney General Merrick B. Garland has sued a state over its voting laws.
content: The Justice Department sued Arizona on Tuesday over a new state law requiring proof of citizenship to vote in a presidential election, saying the Republican-imposed restrictions are a “textbook violation” of federal law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: Amid Scrutiny of N.Y.P.D.’s Sex Crimes Unit, Discipline for Two Former Supervisors
description: Inspector Paul J. Saraceno and Sergeant Keri L. Thompson of the Special Victims Division admitted to misconduct and were removed from their posts.
content: Two former supervisors in the New York Police Department’s troubled sex-crimes division were disciplined in recent months amid an internal affairs investigation into misconduct by the unit’s leadership, according to department records posted online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Famous for Happiness, and Limits on Tourism, Bhutan Will Triple Fees to Visit
description: As Venice and other European hot spots explore permit systems and daily fees to limit the number of tourists, the tiny Buddhist kingdom will require a $200 tax on international visitors when it reopens this fall.
content: The tiny Buddhist kingdom of Bhutan on the eastern edge of the Himalayas, often referred to as “the last Shangri-La” for its abundance of natural beauty, sustainable development and rich cultural heritage, has long resisted the quick financial returns of mass tourism in favor of conservation. The approach is aligned with a cultural philosophy where the country’s wealth and prosperity is measured, through a national happiness index, as an alternative to the gross domestic product.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Salumi and Jerky for Summer Snacking
description: Cured meats from Dickson’s Farmstand Meats include flavors like cacio e pepe and za’atar, and they ship nationwide.
content: In early spring, Jake Dickson of Dickson’s Farmstand Meats created a salumi bar at his Chelsea Market store using locally raised meats. The specialties available on their site now include jerky for the trail and salami for picnics, or summer snacking. The company makes 10 or so salumi in flavors like tres chiles, cacio e pepe, pistachio and orange peel, and finocchiona, along with a wide assortment of jerky, including za’atar, honey and anise, and ghost pepper. All of them are available for nationwide shipping, $10 and up; sizes vary. A gift assortment is $81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shmuel Rosner
title: Israel’s Coalition Didn’t Fail. It Set a New Bar.
description: The departing coalition was created out of necessity — it was the only path to unseat Benjamin Netanyahu — but it almost immediately came under vicious attack.
content: TEL AVIV —  There’s little joy in witnessing one of the most intriguing political experiments of Israel’s recent history come to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caira Blackwell
title: Is Makeup Messing Up My Sunscreen?
description: There’s good news and bad news when it comes to sun protection and cosmetics.
content: Q: I wear a full face of makeup on top of a layer of sunscreen each day. Does that diminish my protection from UV rays?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: Reader Questions: Globe-Trotting Vegetarians and More
description: Looking for old-school Cantonese? Dinner in a beautiful room? We have options.
content: Before I hop into the questions, a special thanks to my colleague Becky Hughes for filling in last week. I feel well rested and energized to answer another round of reader questions. Today we have a newbie looking to try different cuisines, a visitor seeking great Cantonese and a diner who wants to eat in a beautiful space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: When the Czarinas Ruled the Front Row
description: A group of Russian women were once the hottest things at couture, embraced not just by fashion, but by the watching world. Where are they now?
content: Around this time just over a decade ago something happened in fashion that was as rare and unexpected as the sight of Kate Moss in a tutu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim and Amanda Holpuch
title: What We Know About the Shooting in Highland Park
description: Prosecutors lodged first-degree murder charges on Tuesday against a suspect who was taken into custody Monday evening.
content: A gunman shooting from a rooftop killed seven people and wounded dozens more during a Fourth of July celebration in Highland Park, Ill., on Monday morning. A 21-year-old man who was taken into custody Monday evening after an extensive manhunt was charged on Tuesday with seven counts of first-degree murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: One of the Few Potential Bright Spots for Democrats in 2022: The Senate
description: Democrats hope to portray Republican Senate candidates in some of the most competitive midterm races as too far outside the mainstream. For now, it seems to be working.
content: When asked to share their candid thoughts about the Democrats’ chances of hanging onto their House majority in the coming election, party strategists often use words that cannot be printed in a family newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Much More Than Bragging Rights at the Next Barbecue Are at Stake
description: Neither Tatjana Maria nor Ons Jabeur had been to a Grand Slam singles semifinal until this week. The close friends will play each other at Wimbledon on Thursday for a place in the final.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — A working mother of two, Tatjana Maria had the child care under control on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ella Braidwood
title: Will Euro 2022 Be the Payoff on England’s Investment in Women’s Soccer?
description: At least a half-dozen nations will arrive at this summer’s European Championship thinking they can lift the trophy. But the pressure to win might be the highest on the host nation.
content: BURTON-ON-TRENT, England — It was only 13 years ago, England defender Lucy Bronze figures as she scrolls through her memories, when she needed to pack bags in a supermarket to earn the money she needed for her bus fare to Derby, where she and her Sunderland teammates were to play in the Women’s F.A. Cup Final. It was only a couple of years after that when she was still juggling her nascent career at Everton with a job at Domino’s Pizza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel
title: A former employee of Archegos, the collapsed hedge fund, sues for millions in lost pay.
description: A former analyst at the firm said it had forced employees to contribute to a $500 million deferred compensation plan that it told them was guaranteed.
content: A former employee of Archegos, the investment firm that caused a brief market panic when it lost more than $10 billion in a matter of days last year, is suing the firm and its founder, Bill Hwang, plus five former top executives. The lawsuit was filed on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the DealBook newsletter reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: After Another Mass Shooting, New Jersey Tightens Gun Laws
description: The legislation, which Gov. Phil Murphy signed on Tuesday, comes amid a push by states with strict gun laws to work around a Supreme Court ruling aimed at dismantling them.
content: Newly signed legislation will make it more difficult to obtain a handgun license and buy high-capacity rifles in New Jersey, the latest in a patchwork effort by states with strict gun laws to work around a sweeping Supreme Court ruling aimed at dismantling them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Hudson River Tunnel Project Moves Ahead as States Agree to Share Costs
description: A project to build new tunnels from New Jersey to Penn Station moved a step closer to construction with an agreement between New York and New Jersey.
content: For the last 20 years, the plan to dig new train tunnels under the Hudson River — among the most ambitious and important transportation projects in the country — has been repeatedly tripped up by political wrangling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Bryan Avelar
title: A Poor Country Made Bitcoin a National Currency. The Bet Isn’t Paying Off.
description: It brought El Salvador’s president, Nayib Bukele, the adulation of the tech community, but reduced scarce funds and moved the nation closer to default.
content: Bitcoin was meant to transform El Salvador’s economy, catapulting the poor Central American nation into an unlikely harbinger of a financial revolution.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘If You Decide to Flirt With a Stranger’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: If you decide to flirt with a stranger by sliding into his Twitter DMs, brew a cup of tea first. Then, sit. Sip the tea. Breathe deeply. Allow yourself to swell with giddiness. Don’t charge forward, rushing with new messages, just because you cannot tolerate the vulnerability of reaching out. That will result with you picking words in a frenzy, words that you’ll pore over later as you wonder why he stopped replying. It might not be flirtatious to point out dead links on a person’s website; it’s sometimes a conversation ender to ask, “Do you have a wife?” — Jay Vera Summer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: ‘Last night I drank far too much’: How a little-known lawmaker threw Britain’s government into crisis.
description: Chris Pincher’s actions could easily have gone unnoticed if Boris Johnson’s government hadn’t already been troubled.
content: When a little-known member of Britain’s Parliament got drunk at an exclusive club last week and then staggered out into a warm London night, few would have thought that he would throw the government into chaos and threaten Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Sharks Hire Mike Grier as N.H.L.’s First Black General Manager
description: Two days before the annual draft, Grier takes over a team in transition: San Jose missed the past three postseasons and recently fired its coach.
content: Mike Grier, who spent 14 seasons in the N.H.L. as a gritty right wing, on Tuesday was named general manager of the San Jose Sharks, becoming the first Black general manager in the history of a league that just completed its 105th season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Infertility Patients and Doctors Fear Abortion Bans Could Restrict I.V.F.
description: The new state bans don’t explicitly cover embryos created outside the womb, but legal experts say overturning Roe could make it easier to place controls on genetic testing, storage and disposal of them.
content: Anna Nibley Baker, a mother of four in Salt Lake City, is reasonably certain that she and her husband are done building their family. Yet for eight years, since the birth of her last child, conceived through in vitro fertilization, she has thought tenderly of the couple’s three remaining embryos, frozen and stored at a university clinic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Carlos Prieto, Rachelle Bonja, Eric Krupke, Rikki Novetsky, Marc Georges, Anita Badejo, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: The Promises and Pitfalls of the New Gun Law
description: After yet another mass shooting, will the bipartisan legislation actually work?
content: President Biden has heralded the recent gun safety bill as the most significant federal attempt to reduce gun violence in 30 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Corey Kilgannon
title: Alternate-Side Parking Is Back in Full Force: ‘It’s a Pain in the Neck’
description: After a hiatus of twice-a-week street cleanings earlier in the pandemic, New York City has started enforcing full alternate-side parking rules again.
content: After a reprieve of more than two years, full alternate-side parking is back in New York City, requiring some drivers who park on the street to play musical chairs twice a week instead of just once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: How Wall Street Escaped the Crypto Meltdown
description: As cryptocurrency prices plunged and funds failed, strict rules on risky assets helped Wall Street companies sidestep the worst. Retail investors weren’t as lucky.
content: Last November, in the midst of an exuberant cryptocurrency market, analysts at BNP Paribas, a French bank with a Wall Street presence, pulled together a list of 50 stocks they thought were overpriced — including many with strong links to digital assets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Bluer Picture
description: The midterm campaigns for the House and the Senate are shaping up quite differently.
content: The midterm polls continue to look dark for Democrats, as we explained in a newsletter last week. Inflation and Covid disruptions, as well as the normal challenges that a president’s party faces in midterms, are weighing on the party. As a result, the Republicans are heavily favored to retake control of the House.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Russia Advances in East, but Win Takes Harsh Toll
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 5, 2022.
content: “There is a problem with ammunition. For example, for our one shot, they would fire 50 shots. How can you fight this?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Mischievous Creature of Folklore
description: Malgorzata Nowakowska and Eileen Williams constructed this puzzle all too well.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the crossword-constructing duo Malgorzata Nowakowska and Eileen Williams, who are both medical students making their New York Times debut today with a puzzle that pays tribute to an artist whose way with words makes her the perfect subject for a crossword.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Nuclear Power Gets New Push in U.S., Winning Converts
description: With challenges in meeting clean energy goals and new electricity demands, politicians in both parties seek to prolong and even expand reactor use.
content: Driven by the difficulty of meeting clean energy goals and by surging electricity demands, a growing number of political leaders are taking a fresh look at nuclear power — both extending the life of existing reactors and building new ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: Saigon Social Looks Back at Vietnam
description: At her Lower East Side restaurant, the chef Helen Nguyen conjures the country her family left behind.
content: Order the banh beo chen at the downtown Vietnamese restaurant Saigon Social and six will show up, arranged in a circle around a dish of seasoned fish sauce. This is as it should be. Like Mormon missionaries, banh beo chen never travel alone. Typically, each of these soft disks of steamed rice flour is the size of an oyster, and a single banh beo would be about as satisfying as a single bluepoint. One is not a serving. Six is a good start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Gold
title: In This Novel, America and the Weather Are Both Extreme
description: In Bruce Holsinger’s latest novel, “The Displacements,” the world’s first Category 6 hurricane prompts a reckoning.
content: The novel of future catastrophe tends to create some distance between where we are now, where we have been and where we are afraid we might be heading. Margaret Atwood has said that she put nothing in her 1985 dystopian classic, “The Handmaid’s Tale,” that hadn’t already happened. Octavia Butler claimed she was partly inspired by her news-junkie ways to write “Parable of the Sower” (1993) but had hoped it would never have the ring of prophecy. In J.G. Ballard’s 1962 novel, “The Drowned World,” which is set in 2145, the author imagined a punishing climate in which the icecaps have completely melted, and where, for the humans left to study them, “the vast swamps and jungles had been a fabulous laboratory, the submerged cities little more than elaborate pedestals.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: An Embattled N.Y.P.D. Unit
description: It turns out that two supervisors of the Special Victims Division were disciplined in recent months amid an internal affairs investigation into misconduct by the department’s leadership.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll take another look at the Police Department’s embattled Special Victims Division. We’ll also meet a dinosaur that was found in Montana and will be auctioned in Manhattan at the end of the month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Awards Medal of Honor to Vietnam Soldiers for ‘Incredible Heroism’
description: “They went far above and beyond the call of duty,” the president said as he bestowed America’s highest military honor upon four recipients.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Tuesday honored four Vietnam-era soldiers for what he called “acts of incredible heroism,” bestowing on them the Medal of Honor, America’s highest military honor, nearly half a century after the end of the conflict in Southeast Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Judge Clears Distributors of Blame for Opioid Crisis in Hard-Hit County
description: Often described as ground zero for the epidemic, the communities of Cabell County and Huntington, W. Va., had opted out of a settlement and lost their case at trial.
content: A federal judge has ruled that the nation’s three largest drug distributors cannot be held liable for the opioid epidemic in one of the most ravaged counties in the country — a place where 81 million prescription painkillers were shipped over eight years to a population of less than 100,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Liberals Need a Clearer Vision of the Constitution. Here’s What It Could Look Like.
description: The legal scholar Larry Kramer on why the left’s embrace of judicial supremacy was a mistake.
content: For decades now, the conservative legal movement has been on a mission to remake this nation’s laws from the bench. And it’s working. On Friday we released an episode with the legal scholar Kate Shaw that walked through case after case showing how conservative Supreme Court majorities have lurched this country’s laws to the right on guns, voting, gerrymandering, regulatory authority, unions, campaign finance and more in the past 20 years. And if the Dobbs majority is any indication, this rightward shift is just getting started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: The euro hits a 20-year low and U.S. bonds flash a warning sign as economic fears mount.
description: Oil prices tumbled and other markets around the world reflected renewed recession worries.
content: The euro fell to a 20-year low against the U.S. dollar on Tuesday, as fears about the European economy weighed heavily on the currency. It was one of several signs of renewed economic worries around the world, which were also reflected in stocks wobbling, bonds flashing warning signals and oil prices falling sharply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Chiarito and Mitch Smith
title: Highland Park Suspect Was Known to Police; Bought Guns Legally
description: The 21-year-old man was charged with seven counts of first-degree murder a day after the shooting at a Fourth of July parade.
content: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill. — The man accused of killing seven people and wounding dozens of others in a shooting that terrorized a Fourth of July parade had been investigated by the local police before. Officers had responded in 2019 after someone reported that he had tried to kill himself. And they came to his home a few months later — seizing a knife collection — after a family member reported that he had pledged to “kill everyone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford quarterly sales were up slightly from last year, when chip shortages hurt output.
description: The automaker sold 483,688 vehicles in the United States in the second quarter.
content: Ford Motor said Tuesday that it sold 483,688 cars and light trucks in the United States in the second quarter, slightly more than it sold a year earlier, when it was hit particularly hard by the global shortage of computer chips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan and Sarah Cahalan
title: As BA.5 becomes dominant among new U.S. cases, reduced state reporting is blurring the real-time look at the virus.
description: As states report less frequently, changes in the trajectory of the virus are slower to reveal themselves.
content: At a glance, the pandemic picture in the United States may seem remarkably stable. The average number of new confirmed coronavirus cases per day has hardly budged for weeks, hovering between 95,000 and 115,000 a day each day in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Ready-to-Sear Skewers From Xiao Chi Jie in Seattle
description: The Chinese street food restaurant ships nicely spiced marinated boneless beef, lamb and chicken nationally.
content: Xiao Chi Jie, a Chinese street food restaurant in Seattle owned by Caleb Wang and Jen Liao, turned to frozen takeout when the pandemic began. They specialized in soup dumplings, which they began shipping nationally in late 2020. Now they have introduced shao kao skewers with nicely spiced marinated boneless beef, lamb and chicken to sear in minutes on a stovetop, grill or even in an air fryer. They’re an easy nibble with drinks; cook a few for a quick supper, and a platter of them makes a feast. The company also sells dipping sauces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Ask a Stranger For Help
description: It might feel socially risky, but ask anyway. Keep your request simple and direct.
content: “Asking for help is hardly ever as bad as you imagine it will be,” says Vanessa Bohns, a social psychologist and associate professor of organizational behavior at Cornell University. For research purposes, she and colleagues have sent help-seekers out into cities all over the world to request things from 15,000 strangers. Appealing for assistance “feels socially risky,” Bohns says. Ask anyway. When asked for help, most people are happy to comply. “We are a social species,” Bohns says. “We default to being agreeable rather than disagreeable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: The attack in Highland Park was not the only shooting over a violent holiday weekend.
description: As of early Monday morning, at least 57 people had been shot in Chicago alone over the Fourth of July weekend, nine of them fatally.
content: The attack at the Highland Park Fourth of July parade was the largest and highest-profile shooting, but far from the only one, over the holiday weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Maryna Viazovska: Second to none in any dimension.
description: Dr. Viazovska works on a variation of a conjecture introduced 400 years ago by Johannes Kepler, and she is the second woman to win the Fields Medal.
content: Maryna Viazovska, a Ukrainian who is now a professor at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Lausanne, is known for proofs for higher-dimensional equivalents of the stacking of equal- sized spheres. She is also only the second woman ever to win the Fields Medal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: Ukraine’s prime minister says rebuilding will cost $750 billion.
description: World leaders are mapping out the monumental effort to restore a war-battered nation.
content: For Ukrainians living through war, the cost of the conflict is hard to measure: Thousands of people killed, countless homes and buildings destroyed by missiles, families displaced, livelihoods lost. But international leaders are gathering in the lakeside Swiss town of Lugano for a second day on Tuesday in an attempt to do just that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What to Know About California’s Landmark Plastics Law
description: The new legislation requires plastics makers to foot the bill for recycling and restricts single-use plastics.
content: California approved the most sweeping restrictions on plastics in the nation late last week, a move that will most likely reshape the way we shop and recycle over the next decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Peele
title: Cory Booker Wants You to Give Up the White Stuff (Sugar, That Is)
description: Over the long weekend, the New Jersey senator asked his followers to join him in having a “Sugar Free Summer.”
content: On the morning before the Fourth of July, Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, sent a mass email with the subject line “Sugar Free Summer.” It detailed the harms of processed sugar, including the taxes that fund it through subsidies, its health risks and the attendant health care bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Veterans of Carter-Era Inflation Warn That Biden Has Few Tools to Tame Prices
description: President Biden and Democrats face political peril as costs keep rising and midterm elections loom.
content: WASHINGTON — When inflation surged in the late 1970s, President Jimmy Carter convened his top economic advisers for weekly lunch meetings in which they tended to offer overly optimistic forecasts of how high prices would rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim
title: 7 Trump Allies Subpoenaed in Georgia Criminal Investigation
description: Rudy Giuliani, Lindsey Graham, John Eastman and several others in the former president’s orbit were subpoenaed in the election meddling inquiry.
content: Seven advisers and allies of Donald J. Trump, including Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator Lindsey Graham, were subpoenaed on Tuesday in the ongoing criminal investigation in Georgia of election interference by Mr. Trump and his associates. The move was the latest sign that the inquiry has entangled a number of prominent members of Mr. Trump’s orbit, and may cloud the future for the former president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: ‘Growing Up Getty’ Shakes the Dust Off a Family’s Aristocratic Name
description: James Reginato’s new book about the oil baron J. Paul Getty and his many descendants argues that the family isn’t especially dysfunctional — by the standards of the very rich.
content: How cheap was the oil tycoon J. Paul Getty, once known as the richest man in the world?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: U.S. veterans are training Ukrainians near the front lines in the fight against Russia.
description: A democracy came under attack. The United States saw a threat to an ally and also to the entire world order, but it feared that sending troops could incite a nuclear war. So, instead, it supplied weapons. And a small number of American Special Operations trainers started quietly working with the local military.
content: A democracy came under attack. The United States saw a threat to an ally and also to the entire world order, but it feared that sending troops could incite a nuclear war. So, instead, it supplied weapons. And a small number of American Special Operations trainers started quietly working with the local military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: What happens next if Boris Johnson quits?
description: If Boris Johnson were to resign, the Conservative Party would then need to select its next leader, who would become prime minister.
content: If Boris Johnson were to resign, the Conservative Party would then need to select its next leader, who would become prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Stewart
title: Christian Nationalists Are Excited About What Comes Next
description: The way the movement’s leaders see it, Dobbs is just a way station.
content: The shape of the Christian nationalist movement in the post-Roe future is coming into view, and it should terrify anyone concerned for the future of constitutional democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Jumbled Dream of U.S. Chips
description: It’s even harder now to understand what the U.S. wants to accomplish with its computer chip plans.
content: A global shortage of computer chips had stalled the manufacturing of cars, computers and even dog-washing machines. But there are now signs the shortage of chips — the teeny parts that function like the brain or memory in everything electronic — is ending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Britain Gears Up for a Summer of Labor Discontent
description: With energy costs and inflation surging, and taxes and the cost of loans increasing, British workers are demanding higher pay and going on strike with a militancy not seen in years.
content: LONDON — It was one of the more unusual public displays in a city long used to noisy and colorful demonstrations: protesters wearing flowing black gowns and curled horsehair wigs waving placards on Monday outside a London courthouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger and Lila Barth
title: Lonely Last Days in the Suburban Office Park
description: Yes, downtown offices are struggling. But there is a different kind of emptiness in suburban settings that were already isolated and lightly populated by design.
content: The wooded campus that once housed the global headquarters of Toys “R” Us in Wayne, N.J., is 85 percent vacant today. On a weekday, the parking spots for 1,900 cars are mostly empty. The helipad is unused. So is the corporate dining hall, with its views of the serene grounds. Hundreds of cubicles — the spacious old-school kind with the high walls, not the little hot desks popular with employers today — sit empty as the property awaits redevelopment into something entirely new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: An N.F.L. Star’s C.T.E. Diagnosis Offers Only Partial Insight
description: Demaryius Thomas had C.T.E. when he died in December at 33, but the posthumous diagnosis alone does not explain what role football had in the charismatic N.F.L. star’s quick decline.
content: DUBLIN, Ga. — Demaryius Thomas’s parents see their son every day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: As Young Blood Enters South Korean Politics, New (and Old) Barriers Emerge
description: A new law allowed a record number of young people to run in local elections this year. But they face skepticism, cultural hurdles and problems as old as politics itself.
content: SEOUL — Jung Seong-hoon, 22, shared the frustrations of young South Koreans looking at a bleak future: Jobs are scarce, rent is high, and debt is climbing. So last month, he ran for a spot on his local city legislature and won.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 5, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Tuesday, July 5, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Can Fashion Still Shock?
description: From trompe l’oeil to the metaverse, Schiaparelli, Dior and Iris van Herpen offer some answers.
content: PARIS — What’s shocking now?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Kevin McKenzie and Martine van Hamel: On the Zen of Escaping City Life
description: The artistic director of American Ballet Theater and the former dancer ‘drink in the calm’ at a 1904 house in Woodstock, N.Y.
content: Kevin McKenzie and Martine van Hamel were standing in the dining room of their weekend house in Woodstock, N.Y., trying to figure out when they got married.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks
title: ‘Get the Stretcher!’ Life and Death on Ukraine’s Front Line
description: On another day of scorched-earth artillery barrages in the east, a team of Ukrainian medics did their best to stabilize and assure the survivors, with the din of war all around.
content: DONETSK REGION, Ukraine — Between the cracks of mortar fire and the metallic bangs of Russian self-detonating mines, Yurii, a Ukrainian Army medic, readied an intravenous line for the soldier sprawled on the stretcher below him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson quickly fills vacancies, including the health secretary, trying to stabilize his government in crisis.
description: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson moved quickly to plug the holes in his cabinet caused by Tuesday’s resignations of two senior ministers, including the critical job of chancellor of the Exchequer, which went to Nadhim Zahawi, who had been the education secretary.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson moved quickly to plug the holes in his cabinet caused by Tuesday’s resignations of two senior ministers, including the critical job of chancellor of the Exchequer, which went to Nadhim Zahawi, who had been the education secretary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh and Kate Conger
title: Twitter, Challenging Orders to Remove Content, Sues India’s Government
description: Twitter’s lawsuit is part of a broadening battle between the biggest tech companies and governments around the world over who gets to control information and how.
content: Twitter said on Tuesday that it had sued the Indian government, escalating the social media company’s fight in the country as Prime Minister Narendra Modi seeks more control over critical online posts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Krista Tippett Wants You to See All the Hidden Signs of Hope
description: “I see the damage and the pain,” says the longtime host of “On Being.” “I also see people tending to that.”
content: “I see the damage and the pain,” says the longtime host of “On Being.” “I also see people tending to that.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is Liz Cheney Politically Brave? Joe Manchin? Mike Pence? 10 Voters Debate Courage.
description: Ten Americans talked about leadership and bravery — or the lack of it — in politics today.
content: Ten Americans talked about leadership and bravery — or the lack of it — in politics today.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sleep Your Way to Better Heart Health
description: Sleep is now considered an essential factor in good heart health.
content: Sleep is now considered an essential factor in good heart health.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Vietnamese Menu Worth the Wait
description: After more than two years of delays and pivots, Saigon Social is serving traditional food from Vietnam on the Lower East Side.
content: After more than two years of delays and pivots, Saigon Social is serving traditional food from Vietnam on the Lower East Side.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kevin McKenzie and Martine van Hamel’s Upstate Escape
description: The artistic director of American Ballet Theater and the former dancer ‘drink in the calm’ at a 1904 house in Woodstock, N.Y.
content: The artistic director of American Ballet Theater and the former dancer ‘drink in the calm’ at a 1904 house in Woodstock, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Built to Thrive: Four Mindsets Revealed
description: Curious, motivated, optimistic, flexible. We spoke to four passionate achievers about how they found their version of success.
content: Curious, motivated, optimistic, flexible. We spoke to four passionate achievers about how they found their version of success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: B.A. Parker Can’t Get Enough of K-Dramas
description: The new host of NPR’s “Code Switch” podcast counts Donny Hathaway’s voice, 50-minute naps and Otterbein’s Cookies as her essentials.
content: B.A. Parker was a film professor in her 20s when she had to rush her students out of the hall so that she could speak with Ira Glass. She was interviewing for a fellowship with his show, “This American Life.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Our Little Town’: A Fourth of July Parade Turned Deadly
description: “Must each of us lose a loved one before the gun lobby is stopped?” a reader asks. Also: Justice Jackson’s tough task; threats against election workers.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
